bibl.title: Albert H. Young and Kamasaburo Sugiuro v. United States. Affadvit.
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

msIdentifier.repository: National Archives and Records Administration, Seattle Branch, Washington
msIdentifier.collection: RG 21: US District Court, Western Division of Washington, Seatle

div1.p: Exhibit "B" Statement of K. Ito, Made at San Francisco Cal., June 3, 1913 K. Ito sworn by Immigrant Inspector, Thom, M. Fisher.
Q What is your name? A K. Ito
Q When did you first become connected with that house at 1020 Stockton St? A About June last year.
Q How much of that house did you control? A The part known as 1020B
Who did you buy from A Tsumori
In buying did you buy in your own name or the name of your wife? A My wife's name
Q When you bought that house was this girl, Hana, an inmate of it? A She had been there but had ran away before that time.
Q That house was a house of prostitution was it not? A Yes.
You had known Hana and Saito Washio before that had you not? A Yes
Q How long before that? A About 3 years but not together, they had been together about four months.
Q Were you living in that house when Hana went away with Saito? A No I was living at 528 Pine St.
Q You knew about them going away together? A Yes
Q You were called into a consulation in regard to a settlement? A Yes.
Q Who else was called in? A Umeda, Hana, Saito, Washio and myself

Q What was the agreement reached? A It was agreed that Saito was to pay either $1300.00 or $1500., I forget which, to Washio, Saito owed some money at some stores also and it was agreed that he was to take Hana to Sacramento or Frseno for two weeks and make that money. Umeda adn I guaranteed the payment of that money.
Q They didn't return in two weeks did they? A No.
Q You found they had gove north did you not? A Yes
Q Did you get together then and take steps to try to locate Hana and Saito?
Q Washio came to us and said we had guaranteed for them and it was up to us to produce the woman or pay so we did all we could to locate them.

Q Then you went to the Burne Agency and paid them for two days work in Seattle locating Hana did you not? A A man named S. Kodama and Washio went there and paid them $40. I didn';t go with them at that time.
Q Then Umeda went to Seattle, didn't he, to look for Hana? A Yes.
Q He didn't locate her? A No.
Q After he came back Washio went up there? A Yes.
Q Washio sent you a wire that he had then located in Tacoma didn't he? A Yes.
Q Sent you this wire? (Showing wire) A Yes.

Q When you got that what did you do? A Umeda and I employed Nakada to go with us to Burne people. I had received a latter from Washio asking me to get a warrant for Hana in Umeda's name. we asked the Burns people about it and they told us we couldn't get the kind of a warrant we wanted, we could get one for larceny, we weanted a warrant just to get them back here.
Q Did you wire or write Washio that you couldn't get the warrant? A We told him by wire the same day we went to the Burns people.
Q What did you say in that wire? A That we couldn't lend our name to a warrant of that kind.
Q How did you send that wire? A Western Union Addressed to Washio in care of the Great Northern Hotel.
Q Did you get a letter from Washio after that? A No.
You got a wire from him? A Yes.
Q This one? (Showing telegram dated August 9, 1912) A Yes
Q What did you understand by "please have all arrangements made" A I understood that to mean to arrange so there would be no trouble at this end between Saito and Washio and people interested.
Q It was already understood beforehand that if Washio got the girl she was to be brought back to that house was it not? A Yes
Q Then you got this wire also from Washio? (Showing wire dated Aug. 13, 1913) A Yes after I got that wire my wife and I went to the boat and met them.
Q Did you at the time know that Young and Sugiura were coming? A No I didn't, I met them for the first time at the dock.
Q . There was a little trouble at the dock between Saito and some one else was there not? A Yes, Saito and I had some trouble.
Q Then the party went right to your house at 1020 Stockton St? A Yes
Q How long did Young and Sugiura stay there? A About half an hour.

Q What did they have to say? A they told me that Washio had agreed with them thay they should be paid for bringing the girl down and thay they had found Washio hadno money and they wanted mr to raise the money and give it to them.
Q Did they say how much money they were to get? A They said Washio had agreed to give them $800., I told them I didn't agree to give them the money and it was up to them to get it from Washio.

Q What wlse did Young, Sugiura or Washio say at that time? A Young and Sugiura said the agreement with Washio was to pay them $800. for bringing the girl down here but that things didn't go just right so they were willing to settle and take $400. and wanted me to pay them that. Sugiura said he had posed as an interpreter and that Young has possed as an Immigration officer and the woman believeing them $800. to take the chances of bringing this woman here to a house of prostitution and that they wanted their money. They told me later that they had been to see Mr. Gardner of the Immigration offices and had fixed things with him so there would be no trouble but that we must come through with the money to them. Young and Sugiura went to the Imperial hotel, Washio and Hana stayed in my house. The next day I think it was, Umeda and I were sent for by Young and Sugiura and went to the Imperial Hotel to see them, Young and Sugiura and their agreement with Washio and said they couldn't wait for their money and must get back to Seattle and that Umeda and I must raise the money for them. Later in the day Young and Sugiura came to my house Umeda was present also, and there I paid them $200. and later I paid them $50. more.
Who did you pay this money to? A I handed it to Umeda who passed it over on the table, Sugiura picked it up and handed it to Young.

Q Did you see Young and Sugiura after that? A They came the next day and said it was alright for Hana to practice prostitution as they had fixed it with the immigration officers, they had told us at first not to let her do business for a while as they were afraid if we did there would be trouble for all of us, that was the last I saw of them.
Q After that Hana practiced prostitution in that house didn't she? A Yes
Q You after wrote a letter to Sugiura didn't you? A yes
Q Is this the letter? (showing letter) A Yes

Q What do you mean when you say in that letter "what did you tell the Immigration officers about Hana"? A They had told me that they had fixed things in regard to Hana doing business and the Japanese News Paper had printed an article and I wanted to know how he had fixed things and what he has told them when he fixed it, after the News Paper article Nakada phoned me to come to his office, I went there and he told me that the Immigration officers would be after Hana that night or the next morning and told me to get her out of the house, Umeda was there with me, and we got the woman out of the house, took her to a lodging-house on Keaney St., near the City Hall, the house from which she was arrested. The next day Nakada came and told me that the United States Marshal was after myself and Umeda and that we had better hide out, he said "I can fix it if you will come through" I asked him to fix it and he told me to give him $50. and he would fix it so I would be out of California as far as the officers knew. I paid him two $20. and one $10. in gold, then he told me, this $50. you give me is not all for me, I have to buy cigars for the Marshals and give them a piece of it beside.

Q Was there anyone present when you gave him that money? A No, I showed the money to Umeda and told him what I was going to do with it, I forgot to tell you that when we were at the Burns Agency Nakada told us he could get a United States warrant for Hana for $250. The next day after I gave Namasa the $50. Nakada and a Marshal came to my house after Hana, Nakada said the Marshal wants Hana and if you don't produce her he will hold you until she is produced. I told him I couldn't stand for that and Nakada asked me where she was, I told him "I hid her on your instructions, you told me to hide her", finally Umeda took the Marshal to the room and showd him Hana. After my wife was taken to Seattle Nakada told me he would find out about the Seattle case and wanted me to pay him $25. I paid him $15.
I certify the foregoing is a true and full transcript of the atenographic notes made by me at the time statement was ade.
